courses.name: General Introduction to Philosophy
courses.description: Introduction to traditional philosophical problems and methods of philosophical enquiry. Consideration given to different philosophical theories on the nature of reality, man, nature and God; knowledge and how it is acquired; values and social issues.

courses.name: General Introduction to Philosophy - Honors
courses.description: Introduction to traditional philosophical problems and methods of philosophical enquiry. Consideration given to different philosophical theories on the nature of reality, man, nature and God; knowledge and how it is acquired; values and social issues.

courses.name: Introduction to Ethics
courses.description: Introduction to different philosophical theories regarding when acts are morally right rather than wrong; when things are good rather than bad; nature of the "good life", nature of ethical reasoning and justification.

courses.name: Introduction to Ethics - Honors
courses.description: Introduction to different philosophical theories regarding when acts are morally right rather than wrong; when things are good rather than bad; nature of the "good life", nature of ethical reasoning and justification.

courses.name: Introductory Bioethics
courses.description: This course approaches moral problems in biomedical and scientific research from a philosophical perspective.  First, we'll familiarize ourselves with ethics and political philosophy.  Then we'll study the ethical issues that arise in connection with a series of issues, including research involving human and animal subjects, eugenics, the human genome project, cloning and stem cell research.  By thinking about these issues, we learn how to think critically about particular moral quandaries, as well as to uncover and examine some of our deepest moral commitments.

courses.name: Logic and Reasoning
courses.description: Methods of analyzing and evaluating arguments of all types. Uses both informal and formal techniques. Identifies informal fallacies and introduces elementary symbolic logic.

courses.name: Logic and Reasoning-Honors
courses.description: Methods of analyzing and evaluating arguments of all types. Uses both informal and formal techniques. Identifies informal fallacies and introduces elementary symbolic logic.

courses.name: Philosophical Ideas in Literature
courses.description: Philosophical ideas and issues revolving around human freedom as these ideas and issues are embodied in great literary works from Plato through Dostoyevski to Burgess.

courses.name: Topics in Philosophy-Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of philosophical issues to which no regular course in devoted.  Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: The Philosophy of Film
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 2010). Philosophical problems having to do with film.  Topic may include the nature of films, the differences between fiction and documentary film, ethical issues with film and filmmaking.

courses.name: Philosophy: East and West
courses.description: (same as S_A_ST 2100). Compares the interpretation and role of philosophical concepts such as experience, reason, permanence, change, immortality, soul, God, etc., in Indian, Chinese and European traditions.

courses.name: Philosophy and Intellectual Revolution
courses.description: Examines such revolutions as the Copernican, Darwinian, Marxian and Freudian. What are the new views? How is our place in the universe affected? What puzzles arise in replacing old by new views?

courses.name: Philosophy and Human Nature
courses.description: Philosophical exploration and examination of theories of human nature with reference to relevant developments in such sciences as biology, psychology, and economics.

courses.name: The Meaning of Life
courses.description: Does life have meaning, or is it essentially meaningless, absurd?  This course will examine some of answers philosophers have given to this and related questions.

courses.name: Ethics and the Professions
courses.description: Examination of ethical issues confronted by members of different professions such as medicine, law, business, journalism and engineering.

courses.name: Philosophies of War and Peace
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2410). Moral issues about the recourse to war by the nation and the individual's obligations to participate. The nature of peace, social and personal. Special attention to the Vietnam War and the nuclear age.

courses.name: Philosophies of War and Peace - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2410W). Moral issues about the recourse to war by the nation and the individual's obligations to participate. The nature of peace, social and personal. Special attention to the Vietnam War and the nuclear age.

courses.name: Ethical Issues in Business
courses.description: Major theories of moral obligation and justice and their application to business practices. Corporate responsibility, government regulation, investment and production, advertisement, the environment, preferential hiring, etc. through case studies, legal opinions and philosophical analysis.

courses.name: Contemporary Moral Issues
courses.description: Review of the major contemporary ethical theories and their contribution to the resolution of major social issues such as euthanasia, suicide, abortion, capital punishment, violence and war. Emphasis on nature, interests, and rights of persons. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Medical Ethics
courses.description: Considers moral issues posed by developments in biological sciences and medical technology. Topics may include: genetic engineering, abortion and euthanasia, distribution of health care.

courses.name: Philosophy and Gender
courses.description: (same as WGST 2500). A critical examination of central ideas and themes in feminist philosophical thought.  Topics may include:  sex, marriage, parenthood, reproduction, body image, pornography, prostitution.

courses.name: Philosophy and Gender - Honors
courses.description: A critical examination of central ideas and themes in feminist philosophical thought. Topics may include: sex, marriage, parenthood, reproduction, body image, pornography, prostitution.

courses.name: Rational Decisions
courses.description: Principles for making decisions in a rational way. Special attention to principles that use probabilities and utilities. Some discussion of decisions made in conjunction with other people, and decisions made for other people. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing and grade of C or better in MATH 1100 or MATH 1120

courses.name: Elementary Logic
courses.description: (same as LINGST 2700). Introduces a symbolic language for representing the structure of arguments. Presents precise rules for demonstrating the validity of arguments. Covers natural deduction for sentence and predicate logic. Develops skill in constructing derivations. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing and grade of C or better in MATH 1100 or MATH 1120

courses.name: Introduction to Cognitive Science
courses.description: (same as PSYCH 2820 and LINGST 2820).  Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary study of the mind.  After an overview of the foundations of cognitive science as a whole, we will see what particular sectors of it have to say about mental capacities such as vision, language, categorization, and social cognition.

courses.name: Ancient Western Philosophy
courses.description: (same as CL_HUM 3025). Philosophical thought on nature, knowledge, the gods, human life and society, from Thales to Augustine. Emphasis on Plato and Aristotle. The relevance of the ancients to contemporary life.

courses.name: Medieval Philosophy
courses.description: Major thinkers from St. Augustine through 14th century Ockhamists.

courses.name: Modern Philosophy
courses.description: Surveys critical and speculative thinking of modern period from Descartes to Kant in relation to scientific, religious and social movements.

courses.name: Modern Philosophy - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Surveys critical and speculative thinking of modern period from Descartes to Kant in relation to scientific, religious and social movements.

courses.name: 19th Century Philosophy
courses.description: A careful and sympathetic study of some of the major thinkers of this period, notably Kierkegaard and Nietzsche.

courses.name: Existentialism
courses.description: The nature of human existence, the meaning of life, the relation of the individual to nature, society, and any gods that may be, according to Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Sartre, de Beauvoir, Camus and others. Students are encouraged to come to grips with the issues in relation to their own lives.

courses.name: 20th Century Philosophy
courses.description: The course will be a survey of some of the notable philosophers/thinkers whose contributions have been made in the twentieth century.

courses.name: Selected Modern Philosophers
courses.description: Advanced study of a particular philosopher or a number of philosophers from the same school in the modern period. May be taken twice for credit with permission of the department.

courses.name: Selected Contemporary Philosophers
courses.description: Advanced study of a particular contemporary philosopher or philosophers.  May be taken twice for credit with permission of the department.

courses.name: Topics in Philosophy-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing and two courses in Philosophy, or instructor's consent; departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Topics in Philosophy-Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent for repetition.
courses.recommendation: two courses in Philosophy, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Philosophy of Language
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.

courses.name: Advanced Logic
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4110; cross-leveled with PHIL 7110). Presents the method of truth trees for sentence and predicate logic. Examines proofs concerning the decidability, soundness, and completeness of formal systems. Emphasizes the theory of formal systems. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Logic
courses.description: Elementary set theory. Modal logic, the logic of possibility and necessity.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing and either PHIL 2700 or PHIL 4110

courses.name: Probability and Induction
courses.description: This course studies probability, its various interpretations, and its basic principles.  It identifies forms of reasoning that establish the probability of a conclusion.  The methods of reasoning it treats are at the heart of science and practical affairs.

courses.name: Metaphysics
courses.description: Metaphysics studies what there is and how things are, most generally speaking. Topics may include realism versus nominalism, substance and attribute, facts, modality, identity and causality.
courses.recommendation: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200

courses.name: Philosophy of Mind
courses.description: Considers theories and arguments in contemporary philosophy of mind, focusing on the nature of mental states, their relation to brain states and the plausibility of various materialist theories of the mind.

courses.name: Philosophy of Religion
courses.description: Considers basis for and nature of religious beliefs.

courses.name: Epistemology
courses.description: An examination of contemporary philosophical theories concerning the nature, sources and limits of knowledge and justified belief.
courses.recommendation: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000, PHIL 3200

courses.name: Philosophy of Science
courses.description: Why believe the scientific world-view? What, if anything, is the scientific method? Are today's theories really superior to past theories? Examines contemporary philosophical answers to such questions.

courses.name: Philosophy of History
courses.description: Readings from classic and contemporary philosophers of history. Problems about nature and limits of historical knowledge; relation between history and other disciplines; the existence, nature, and kinds of historical laws.

courses.name: Philosophy of Biology
courses.description: A survey of philosophical problems arising from consideration of evolutionary theory and the biological sciences.  Topics may include reductionism, sociobiology, biological laws, and epistemic problems relating to evolutionary theory.

courses.name: Theories of Ethics
courses.description: Normative and meta-ethical theories. Topics may include the rationality and objectivity of morality, the meaning of moral language, the differences between deontological, utilitarian and virtue theories.

courses.name: Political and Social Philosophy
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 4600). Contemporary and/or historical theories of justice and the state. Utilitarianism, Liberalism, Libertarianism, Marxism, Communitarianism and Feminism may be among the views covered.

courses.name: Philosophy of Law
courses.description: What is law? Are there pre- or trans-legal rights? Is punishment justifiable? How can judicial decisions be justified? What are the relations between law and morality?

courses.name: Marxism
courses.description: A philosophical examination of (a) the notion of critique as seen in Marx's early and middle writings, and (b) specific topics by such authors as Lenin, Lukacs and Plekhanov.

courses.name: Aesthetics
courses.description: Typical components of art; theories of art as representation, form, expression; relation of art to value.

courses.name: Aesthetics-Writing Intensive
courses.description: Typical components of art; theories of art as representation, form, expression; relation of art to value.

courses.name: Asian Philosophy
courses.description: (same as S_A_ST 4800). This course traces the origins of Indian and Chinese philosophical world views. Included are the major ideas in Hindu, Jaina, and Buddhist thought in India, and Taoism and Confucianism in China. Emphasis is placed on the diverse, assimilative, and pragmatic nature of Indian thought and its impact on contemporary Asian philosophy.

courses.name: Philosophy of India
courses.description: (same as S_A_ST 4810). General development of Indian philosophy.

courses.name: Special Readings in Philosophy
courses.description: Special Readings in Philosophy.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Philosophy
courses.description: A capstone course required of and only open to senior Philosophy majors. Course content will vary, depending on the professor teaching the course.

courses.name: Senior Seminar in Philosophy - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A capstone course required of and only open to senior Philosophy majors. Course content will vary, depending on the professor teaching the course.

courses.name: Honors I in Philosophy
courses.description: Special work for Honors candidates.

courses.name: Honors II in Philosophy
courses.description: Special work for Honors candidates.

courses.name: Topics in Philosophy-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Topics in Philosophy-Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Departmental consent for repetition.

courses.name: Philosophy of Language
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.
courses.recommendation: Some work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200

courses.name: Advanced Logic
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7110; cross-leveled with PHIL 4110, LINGST 4110). Presents the method of truth trees for sentence and predicate logic. Examines proofs concerning the decidability, soundness, and completeness of formal systems. Emphasizes the theory of formal systems.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Logic
courses.description: Elementary set theory. Modal logic, the logic of possibility and necessity.

courses.name: Probability and Induction
courses.description: This course studies probability, its various interpretations, and its basic principles.  It identifies forms of reasoning that establish the probability of a conclusion.  The methods of reasoning it treats are at the heart of science and practical affairs.

courses.name: Metaphysics
courses.description: Metaphysics studies what there is and how things are, most generally speaking. Topics may include realism versus nominalism, substance and attribute, facts, modality, identity and causality.
courses.recommendation: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200

courses.name: Philosophy of Mind
courses.description: Considers theories and arguments in contemporary philosophy of mind, focusing on the nature of mental states, their relation to brain states and the plausibility of various materialist theories of the mind.

courses.name: Philosophy of Religion
courses.description: Considers basis for and nature of religious beliefs. Philosophical approaches to religion, cultural implications of religion, psychoanalysis and religion, mysticism and myth.

courses.name: Epistemology
courses.description: An examination of contemporary philosophical theories concerning the nature, sources and limits of knowledge and justified belief.
courses.recommendation: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000, or PHIL 3200

courses.name: Philosophy of Science
courses.description: Why believe the scientific world-view? What, if anything, is the scientific method? Are today's theories really superior to the past theories? Examines contemporary philosophical answers to such questions.

courses.name: Philosophy of History
courses.description: Readings from classic and contemporary philosophers of history. Problems about nature and limits of historical knowledge; relation between history and other disciplines; the existence, nature, and kinds of historical laws.

courses.name: Philosophy of Biology
courses.description: A survey of philosophical problems arising from consideration of evolutionary theory and the biological sciences. Topics may include reductionism, sociobiology, biological laws, and epistemic problems relating to evolutionary theory.

courses.name: Theories of Ethics
courses.description: Normative and meta-ethical theories. Topics may include the rationality and objectivity of morality, the meaning of moral language, the differences between deontological, utilitarian and virtue theories.

courses.name: Political and Social Philosophy
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 4600). Contemporary and/or historical theories of justice and the state. Utilitarianism, Liberalism, Libertarianism, Marxism, Communitarianism and Feminism may be among the views covered.

courses.name: Philosophy of Law
courses.description: What is law? Are there pre- or trans-legal rights? Is punishment justifiable? How can judicial decisions be justified? What are the relations between law and morality?

courses.name: Marxism
courses.description: A philosophical examination of (a) the notion of critique as seen in Marx's early and middle writings, and (b) specific topics by such authors as Lenin, Lukacs and Plekhanov.

courses.name: Aesthetics
courses.description: Typical components of art; theories of art as representation, form, expression; relation of art to value.

courses.name: Asian Philosophy
courses.description: (same as S_A_ST 4800). This course traces the origins of Indian and Chinese philosophical world views. Included are the major ideas in Hindu, Jaina, and Buddhist thought in India, and Taoism and Confucianism in China. Emphasis is placed on the diverse, assimilative, and pragmatic nature of Indian thought and its impact on contemporary Asian philosophy.

courses.name: Philosophy of India
courses.description: (same as S_A_ST 4810). General development of Indian philosophy.

courses.name: Special Readings in Philosophy
courses.description: Special Readings in Philosophy.

courses.name: Research in Philosophy
courses.description: Research not leading to thesis. Graded S/U only.

courses.name: Protoseminar in Philosophy
courses.description: Introduction to graduate level work in philosophy. Required of all students entering the program, in the first year. An intensive workshop focused on skills rather than any particular philosophical content.
courses.prerequisites: restricted to first year graduate students

courses.name: Teaching of Philosophy I
courses.description: Seminar meetings on course design, teaching methods, the evaluation of teaching, grading, instructor obligations, and teaching aids. Some individualized instruction, including help preparing for and assessing the effectiveness of practice teaching.

courses.name: Teaching of Philosophy II
courses.description: A sequel to PHIL 8210. Includes a re-examination of end of semester tasks such as the composition and grading of finals and the assignment of course grades.

courses.name: Dissertation Seminar
courses.description: The course will address writing and time management for Ph.D. students writing a dissertation.  Also discussed will be preparation for the academic job market in philosophy, especially the development of an application dossier. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Metaphysics: A Survey
courses.description: A graduate-level survey of central issues in metaphysics.  May be repeated up to 6 hours of credit.

courses.name: Philosophy of Mind
courses.description: A graduate-level survey of central issues in the philosophy of mind.

courses.name: Epistemology
courses.description: A graduate-level survey of central issues is epistemology.

courses.name: Philosophy of Language: A Survey
courses.description: A graduate-level survey of central issues in philosophy of language.

courses.name: Topics in Philosophy
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics.  Need departmental consent for repetition.

courses.name: Indian Philosophy
courses.description: Reality, levels of being, status of the world, nature of knowledge in Indian philosophy in relations in Advaita Vendanta system of Samkara.

courses.name: Plato
courses.description: Advanced studies in Plato; emphasis on recent scholarship.

courses.name: Aristotle
courses.description: Advanced studies in Aristotle; emphasis on recent scholarship.

courses.name: Medieval Thinkers
courses.description: Selected works of one or more: Augustine, Avicenna, Anselm, Maimonides, Aquinas, Scotus, Ockham. Not a survey.

courses.name: Research in Philosophy
courses.description: Work toward preparation of thesis or dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: The Rationalists
courses.description: Interpretation and evaluation of major works of Descartes, Leibniz, and/or Spinoza in relation to their historical context and current philosophical problems.

courses.name: The Empiricists
courses.description: Epistemological and metaphysical doctrines of Locke, Berkeley and Hume.

courses.name: Kant
courses.description: Critique of Pure Reason: historical context, meaning and cohesion of its claims, critical assessment of them.

courses.name: Hegel
courses.description: Phenomenology of Spirit: historical context, meaning and cohesion of its claims, critical assessment of them.

courses.name: Marxism
courses.description: Basic works of Marx and his successors.

courses.name: Whitehead
courses.description: Process and Reality and other works. Contributions to metaphysics, theology, epistemology, and philosophy of science.

courses.name: Russell and Wittgenstein
courses.description: Each initially defends, but then rejects logical atomism. Metaphysical and epistemological themes of such intellectual phases and shifts of one or both philosophers.

courses.name: Heidegger
courses.description: Being and Time: historical context, meaning and cohesion of its claims, critical assessment of them.

courses.name: Existentialism
courses.description: Being and Nothingness and other philosophy and literary works.

courses.name: Phenomenology
courses.description: Selected works of Husserl and other phenomenological thinkers. Implications for epistemology, science, metaphysics, ethics, and other philosophical topics.

courses.name: Recent Anglo-American Philosophy
courses.description: Topics on which current philosophers of the Anglo-American or Analytic tradition are concentrating.

courses.name: Recent Continental Philosophy
courses.description: Topics on which current philosophers on the European continent are concentrating.

courses.name: Applied Ethics
courses.description: Methods for applying normative ethical theories to personal and social moral problems, illustrated by application of consequentialist, deontological and virtue-centered theories to such problems as euthanisia, capital punishment, pornography, world hunger, war and environmentalism.

courses.name: Social and Political Philosophy
courses.description: Topics of current interest in social and political philosophy. generally one of the following: social contract theory, utiltarianism, voting procedures, or convention.
courses.prerequisites: PHIL 4600 or instructor's consent and graduate Philosophy student

courses.name: Aesthetics
courses.description: Theories of art and beauty, the aesthetic experience, the physical work of art, the role of the artist; art and other human concerns.

courses.name: Topics in the History of Ethics
courses.description: Advanced study of the ethical views of major historical figures ancient and/or modern.

courses.name: History of Eastern Ethics
courses.description: Historical survey of major eastern ethical theories. Explores broad range of ethical theories developed in Asia: Hindu and Buddhist in India; Toaism and Confucianism in China; and Zen in Japan.

courses.name: Decision Theory
courses.description: Principles for making rational decisions, including principles of expected utility theory, game theory, and social choice theory. A survey of basic ideas and an introduction to selected research topics.

courses.name: Ethical Theory
courses.description: Contemporary theories of the right and the good. Metaethical topics such as moral language, reasoning, and justification.

courses.name: Metaphysics
courses.description: Theories of the categories and structures of reality, e.g., appearance and reality, causality, space and time, God, Nature, the human being.

courses.name: Philosophy of Mind and Psychology
courses.description: Survey of important recent work in contemporary philosophy of mind and psychology. Graduate seminar.

courses.name: Foundations of Cognitive Science
courses.description: Examination of philosophical questions arising in cognitive science concerning, for instance, the nature of computation and representation, inter-disciplinary relations, the nature of cognitive scientific explanation, and its relation to folk psychological explanation.

courses.name: Epistemology
courses.description: Knowledge and opinion, the types, sources, and extent of knowledge, according to a variety of views.

courses.name: Philosophy of Science
courses.description: Examines central issues in general philosophy of science concerning the scientific method and the role in it of observation, the nature of rational theory-choice, progress, and the status of theories postulating unobservables.

courses.name: Philosophy of Language
courses.description: Topics of current interest in the philosophy of language.

courses.name: Philosophy of Biology
courses.description: Philosophical problems relating to the life sciences, with attention given especially to explanation and reductionism in biology.

courses.name: Seminar in Logic
courses.description: Topics of current interest in logic. Generally one of the following: inductive logic, set theory, conditionals, epistemic logic, or formal semantics.

courses.name: Seminar in Philosophy
courses.description: Special topics. May be repeated for credit.
